text: What do you notice about different kinds of comparison statements?

Student responses should build on their current use of additive relationships in making comparisons to also include comparison statements that employ multiplicative relationships. This is a chance to pre-assess where students are in their understanding. There can be a range of answers.

Students may notice the following:

  • Some comparisons include one number, and others include two numbers.
  • The least sophisticated but probably most likely at this time might just discuss different types of comparison statements. For example, students might mention using "for every" statements ad fraction statements. If many students are here, don't be concerned. This problem is a good pre-assessment for the whole unit. You will have time as the unit progresses to help students develop deeper mathematical understandings.
  • Comparisons may use fractions, percentages, whole numbers, or "for every" or "for each" language.
  • Some comparisons use multiplication, and others use addition.
  • The statements that compare two or more values for the same thing may come directly from the context, or the values may be scaled.
  • The statements help you think about relative sizesâ€”or relationships between quantities.
  • Another sophisticated way to look at the comparison statements at this time would be to contrast the multiplicative statements with the additive statements.
